subject: History
title: The Baghdad Battery
description: A 60-second lesson on The Baghdad Battery.

hook.text: A 2,000-year-old clay jar from Iraq looks like a primitive battery. If it is, someone invented electricity in antiquity.

buildup.text: The jar holds a copper cylinder and iron rod. Filled with an acidic liquid like vinegar, it generates a small voltage.

discovery.text: Discovered near Baghdad in 1938, it dates to the Parthian period (250 BCâ€“224 AD).

twist.text: Replicas produce about 1 voltâ€”enough for electroplating gold onto jewelry. But no electroplated artifacts exist.

climax.text: Skeptics argue it was just a storage jar for scrolls. The battery theory is fascinating but unproven.

punchline.text: It might be a batteryâ€”or just a very famous jar.

quiz.question: What is the main argument against the Baghdad Battery theory?
options: The jar is too old to have contained metal components
No electroplated artifacts from that era have been found
The voltage produced is too low to serve any purpose
